Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear sampling theory for signals with finite rate of innovation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sun
DMS-1109063

The investigator develops a new mathematical framework for nonlinear sampling and recovery of signals with finite rate of innovation from theoretical viewpoint and in practical realization. The investigator works on several fundamental problems concerning the recovery of a signal from its noisy sampled data, the exploration of efficient algorithmic methods in the presence of substantial noise, and the application of the novel sampling methodology to engineering problems. This interdisciplinary project is based on the observations that signals in many engineering problems have finite rate of innovation and could be approximated by signals with sparse representations, and that the sampling process has strong neighbor dependency.

Sampling theory is one of the most basic and fascinating topics in mathematical science and in engineering sciences. In engineering applications, such as Global Positioning Systems (GPS), Ultra-wideband (UWB) ranging systems in communication, and mass spectrometry in medical diagnosis, noisy sampled data are obtained, real-time recovery is preferred, and very accurate restoration is crucial for meaningful justification. Standard Fourier approaches and conventional sampling techniques are inapplicable in such problems. The challenge resides in the requirement of rapid, accurate, and robust recovery. The investigator applies calculus for infinite matrices and introduces novel compressive techniques to tackle fundamental sampling problems. Success in the project could be both mathematically fundamental and technologically important, and has potential impact in the strategic areas of information technology and biotechnology.

The main goal of the project is on  nonlinear sampling theory for signals with finite rate of innovation both from a theoretical viewpoint and in practical realization.

The PI have thirteen journal papers already published and accepted. He gave more than twenty-five talks in professional conferences and universities around the world. He supervised two PhD students and one master student worked in  various aspects of the project. The PI made contributions on several topics on sampling theory, including 1) nonlinear sampling problem in Banach spaces,  2)  mathematical safeguard of sparse stochastic process, 3)  mathematical framework on spatially distributed systems for signal sampling and reconstruction,  4) Galerkin method for real-time signal reconstruction,  5) sparse wavelet signal reconstructions from their Fourier measurements, 6) universal capacity limit of transmission channels, and  7) the long-standing abc-problem for Gabor systems.

1. The fidelity measurement of perceptual signals, such as acoustic and visual signals,  might not be well measured by the square error.  Alternatives of the fidelity measure are weighted norms for signals living in some Banach spaces. The PI extended  strict monotonicity from Hilbert spaces to Banach spaces and proposed an iteration algorithm to solve nonlinear functional equations in Banach spaces. This finding has been used to  locally identification and qualification of  innovation positions and  amplitudes of signals with finite rate of innovation.

2.. The fractional Laplacian has tight link to splines,  fractional Brownian motion, and signal processing. The PI and his collaborators found the unique left-inverse of the fractional Laplacian with the dilation-invariant and integrable property. This finding provides mathematical safeguard  to the specification of sparse stochastic  processes with finite rate of innovation.

3. A spatially distributed system consists of huge amounts of small sensing devices with limited computing and telecommunication capabilities.It has been widely used in multivehicle and multirobot networks, wireless sensor networks, smart grids, etc. Recent technological advances have opened up possibilities to deploy spatially distributed systems for signal sampling and reconstruction. The PI and his collaborators introduced a graph structure for such spatially distributed system  and a coupling technique for signal sampling and reconstruction. This mathematical framework has been used to design robust spatially distributed system against supplement, replacement and impairment of agents,  and to develop distributed algorithms for  suboptimal signal approximation in the presence of bounded sampling noises.

4. Real-time signal reconstruction is crucial in lots of engineering applications.
In most of  sampling procedures in those applications, only finitely many samples are available. Lot of research has been done, but a general framework is still missing.
